45.heading: Eisen, Armand.
45.title: "Film and Comic Art : A Critique of the Purist View"
45.author: Armand Eisen
45.appears_in: p. 12-15 in The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Spring 1974)
notes: SUMMARY: "Rudolph Arnheim declares in his landmark Film as Art, 'The indirectness of language ... makes words fade into meaningless noise when they are forced to compete on an equal footing with visual and auditory action.' This is representative of the purist stand that film with sound and comics with dialogue and prose are hybrid, uncontrolled forms of artistic expression. The author argues that the 'sound' dimension is vital to the functional object of emotional involvement and aesthetically sound as partner to visual storytelling."

80.heading: Eisenhower, Dwight David, 1890-1969.
80.title: "Lucille Van Pelt on the First Tee, Please"
80.author: by Charles M
notes: Summary: Lucy has entered a golf tournament, and worries about playing against Sam Snead, Ben Hogan, and Ike. Charlie Brown reminds her that it's a women's tournament.

This Sunday strip is reproduced as part of a letter to the editor, as evidence that grownups (here only from the shoulders down) sometimes appeared in Peanuts. p. 14 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).

81.heading: Eisenhower, Dwight David, 1890-1969.
81.title: "Our Fighting Generals : an Inspiring True Story"
81.author: by Carter Sprague
81.appears_in: 3 p. text in Real Life Comics, no. 16 (Mar. 1944).
notes: "America's gallant army chiefs have a big job ahead of them, and they are dovetailing their efforts with the United Nations' master plan for defeat of the Axis!"
Sections on George C. Marshall, Henry H. 'Hap' Arnold, Lesley J. McNair, Dwight D. Eisenhower, George C. Patton, Mark Wayne Clark, and Douglas MacArthur.
